subject: Sleep
title: Diet and Sleep Patterns
description: A 60-second lesson on Diet and Sleep Patterns.

hook.text: Lions sleep 20 hours after a kill but barely rest when hunting. A cow sleeps four hours because grass takes all day to eat.

buildup.text: Carnivores generally sleep more than herbivores because meat is calorie-dense and requires less foraging time.

discovery.text: Herbivores must eat for 8 to 16 hours daily just to meet caloric needs, leaving little time for sleep.

twist.text: Omnivores fall in between. Their flexible diet gives them moderate sleep amounts, just like humans.

climax.text: Diet doesn't cause sleep duration. But it creates the time budget that constrains how much sleep is possible.

punchline.text: What you eat determines how much time is left for sleep.

quiz.question: Why do herbivores generally sleep less than carnivores?
options: They must spend 8 to 16 hours eating to meet caloric needs
